author: Special Correspondent
text:
JACTTA’s demands to be put forth to Chief Minister

Representatives of the Joint Action Council of Tamil Nadu Teachers Association were invited for a meeting with education department officials and ministers but the three-hour meeting ended with no promise from the government.

JACTTA has five demands – salaries for secondary grade teachers on a par with central government teachers; scrapping of the new contributory pension scheme and continuance of the old pension scheme; separate school education policy for the state and a check on matriculation schools that follow their own syllabi till class IX. The teachers wanted the government to annul GO no 266 and give preference to teachers with a PG degree for promotions. They also wanted an assurance that the 12,000 teachers at the Adi Dravida Welfare Schools be permitted to undergo transfer counselling in their respective districts instead of being asked to come to Chennai. The representatives said GO no. 132 should be abolished and subjects like agriculture and carpentry should be taught by trained teachers. The meeting was chaired by ministers of finance, electricity, school education, higher education and local bodies. The secretaries of finance and school education and the elementary school education director also participated. But at the end of the meeting the teachers did not receive any positive response to their demand.

“We were told that our demands would be put forth to the Chief Minister who will take a decision,” said JACTTA coordinator P.K. Ilamaran. The association is the umbrella body for 18 organisations representing the teachers in the State.
title: No positive outcome at teachers-Ministers meet
